questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not used for the prophylaxis of migraine?
Drug for HIV induced lipodystrophy:
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - T

questions.text: An elderly woman on treatment for migraine presents with chest pain. She has a previous history of angina/MI. Which of the following mechanisms of the prescribed drug for migraine might have caused this presentation?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - 5-HT agonist

Migraine

Pathophysiology

  • Migraine is characterized by a pulsating unilateral headache that comes in bouts lasting 4-48 hours and is associated with nausea, vomiting, sensitivity to light and sound, flashes of light, and vertigo.
  • 5th cranial nerve stimulation (5-HT1F receptor) → Release of neurotransmitters like CGRP, neurokinin, Nitrous Oxide, 5-HT → Dilation of meningeal vessels causing headache

Drugs used in acute migraine

  • Triptans: Decrease the release of CGRP and cause vasoconstriction. E.g., Sumatriptan, Rizatriptan.
  • CGRP ligand blockers: Eptinezumab, Fremanezumab
  • CGRP receptor blockers: Rimegepant
  • 5-HT1F agonist: Causes inhibition of neuronal firing. E.g., Lasmiditan
  • Ergot alkaloids: Vasoconstrictor. E.g., Ergotamine
  • D2 Blockers: Metoclopramide
  • Opioids and NSAIDs

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about the drugs used in Gout? A. Aspirin is not used as it decreases uric acid excretion B. Diclofenac is used as it concentrates in the joint C. Indomethacin is used as it acts by multiple pathways D. Aspirin is used as it is the most powerful NSAID

options.label: D
options.text: Aspirin is used as it is the most powerful NSAIDC & D

questions.explanation: Correct Answer A - A, B & C

questions.text: Pegloticase is used in the management of?
questions.explanation:
Drugs for acute attack of gout

DOC- NSAIDS

  • Except for aspirin and paracetamol
  • Anti-inflammatory

Colchicine

  • MOA: microtubule inhibitor
  • Used in acute attacks of gout and familial Mediterranean fever and is also the DOC for karyotyping

Corticosteroids
  • Intra articular injections, avoid oral route
  • Immunosuppressive and anti-inflammatory

Drugs for chronic gout

Xanthine oxidase inhibitors
  • Drugs include Allopurinol (DOC), Oxipurinol, Febuxostat
  • MOA: Blocks xanthine oxidase enzyme → Inhibits the conversion of hypoxanthine to uric acid in the liver

Uric acid oxidase enzyme
  • Drugs include Pegloticase and Rasburicase
  • MOA: Uric acid is converted to allantoin and excreted in urine

Uricosuric agents
  • Drugs include Probenecid, Benzbromaron, Sulfinpyrazone, Lesinurad
  • MOA: Inhibit OATP transporter/URAT-1 in the kidney → inhibits reabsorption of uric acid → increased excretion of uric acid.

 

(OATP - Organic anion transport protein, URAT-1 - Uric acid transporter)

questions.text: Which medication can be administered to reduce the frequency of future headache episodes in a 26-year-old female patient who experiences one-sided pulsating headaches accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and finds relief in a dimly lit environment?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Propranolol

Use of propranolol

Drug of choice
  • Migraine prophylaxis
  • Essential tremors
  • Aortic dissection if they also have hypertension

Other Uses
  • Hypertension-second-line drugs
  • Stable angina
  • Cardiac arrhythmias
  • Congestive heart failure
  • Thyrotoxicosis
  • Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (Improve cardiac output).
  • Myocardial infarction (Ml): Secondary prophylaxis of Ml and myocardial salvage during evolution of Ml (decreases mortality).

Acute management of migraine attack

  • Triptans: Decrease the release of CGRP and cause vasoconstriction. E.g., Sumatriptan, Rizatriptan.
  • CGRP ligand blockers: Eptinezumab, Fremanezumab
  • CGRP receptor blockers: Rimegepant
  • 5-HT1F agonist: Causes inhibition of neuronal firing. E.g., Lasmiditan
  • Ergot alkaloids: Vasoconstrictor. E.g., Ergotamine
  • D2 Blockers: Metoclopramide
  • Opioids and NSAIDs

Prophylaxis of migraine

  • Propranolol (Beta-blocker, DOC for migraine prophylaxis).
  • Flunarizine (Calcium channel blocker)
  • Cyproheptadine: (Antihistamine that can help alleviate migraine symptoms).
  • Candesartan: (Angiotensin II receptor blocker).
  • Clonidine
  • Pizotifen (Serotonin antagonist that can help reduce migraine frequency).
  • Gabapentin, valproate, nortriptyline, and topiramate are medications that can help manage migraine symptoms by releasing the neurotransmitter GABA.
  • Topiramate
  • Methysergide (Manages migraine symptoms by blocking serotonin receptors).

questions.text: A patient took a drug for migraine treatment, following which there was numbness, and his hand appeared as below. What is the possible drug that was taken?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Dihydroergotamine

Dihydroergotamine

Drug class

Ergot alkaloids

MOA

Partial agonist activity at 5HT1B/1D receptors causes vasoconstriction, reducing migraine-associated inflammation.

Uses

Acute migraine attack

Side effects

  • Peripheral vasoconstriction
    • Manifest as numbness, tingling, and discolouration of the fingers, commonly referred to as Raynaud's phenomenon.
    • Discolouration of fingers - White → Blue→ Red
    • It can lead to gangrene of extremities and organs with end arteries.
  • Nausea and vomiting
  • Paradoxical headache and dizziness
  • Flushing
  • Nasal congestion
  • Chest pain
  • Muscle pain

questions.text: What is Zileuton's mechanism of action?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer B - 5-Lipooxygenase inh

questions.text: Which of the following DMARD uses require regular monitoring of visual acuity and fundus examination?
questions.explanation:
Hydroxychloroquine

MAO

Hydroxychloroquine⟶ Lysosome Accumulation ⟶ ↑ Lysosomal pH ⟶ Inhibits Antigen Processing ⟶ ↓ Antigen-MHC Presentation ⟶ ↓ T-Cell Activation ⟶ Inhibits TLRs ⟶ ↓ Pro-inflammatory Cytokines ⟶ ↓ Inflammation in RA

Uses
  • Rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
  • Prevention and treatment of malaria
  • Autoimmune diseases like Sjögren's syndrome

Side Effects
  • Gastrointestinal (nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea)
  • Dermatological (rash, pigmentation changes)
  • Ocular toxicity:
    • Vortex keratopathy (cornea verticallata)
    • Posterior subcapsular cataract
    • Bull’s eye retinopathy (deposits like concentric rings in the retina)
  • Cardiovascular (cardiomyopathy, QT prolongation)
  • Neurological (headache, dizziness)
  • Hematologic (anaemia, leukopenia)

Note
  • Regular ophthalmologic examinations to monitor for retinal toxicity.
  • The maximum safe dose of hydroxychloroquine to minimise the risk of bull's-eye maculopathy is recommended to be 5 mg/kg of real body weight per day.

questions.text: Mechanism of action of allopurinol is?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Xanthine oxidase inh

questions.text: A patient with chronic kidney disease underwent a nephrectomy. Which of the following can be administered as a postoperative analgesic in this patient?

What is the initial treatment of choice for chronic gout in a 52-year-old woman with hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, severe pain, and swelling in her left great toe, sporadic similar episodes over the past 3 years, and a daily intake of 6 beers?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A

Target

Drugs

Use
Xanthine Oxidase

Xanthine Oxidase inhibitors

  • Non-purine- Febuxostat (no-allergy)
    • Purine - Allopurinol (cause allergy)

Hyperuricemia

Gout
Uric acid elimination 

Uricosuric drugs:

Probenecid, Sulfinpyrazone 

Benzbromarone, Lesinurad, and Losartan

 Eliminating uric acid through urine

questions.text: What is the most suitable medication for alleviating the symptoms of a 56-year-old postmenopausal woman who has been experiencing worsening pain and swelling in her left knee for the past 6 months? She has a medical history of peptic ulcer disease and is currently taking cimetidine. On examination, palpable crepitus and restricted range of motion are observed in her left knee.
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B: 

Drugs

Properties

Indomethacin
  • Decreases Neutrophil Chemotaxis.
  • Additional anti-inflammatory property
  • It is used to treat osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis and Gout.
  • It is used to close Patent Ductus Arteriosus.
  • Adverse effects: Severe Frontal Headache, Psychosis, Hallucinations and Suicidal tendencies.
  • Contradictions: Patients with Epilepsy, Depression, and Psychotic problems.

Ibuprofen
  • It is used as an Analgesic in children
  • It is used to close Patent Ductus Arteriosus
  • Adverse effect: Aseptic Meningitis

Mefenamic Acid
  • It gets concentrated in the uterus and decreases the prostaglandin activity
  • It has antipyretic properties.
  • It is used to treat dysmenorrhoea.

Paracetamol

  • It is called Acetaminophen
  • Good analgesic and antipyretic drug (Proposed MOA is it inhibits COX 3 in hypothalamus)
  • However, it is a poor anti-inflammatory drug. (The proposed theory is called peroxide theory. Peroxides in the body will not allow the drug to inhibit COX)
  • It is preferred in children, Bronchial asthma, safest analgesic in CKD, analgesic of choice in Osteoarthritis, safe in pregnancy and lactating mother
  • In PCM overdose the NABQI is not metabolised by glutathione leading to hepatotoxicity.
  • N-acetyl cysteine is the antidote in PCM overdose. It replenishes Glutathione.

Ketorolac
  • It is given intravenously and is used for treating post-operative conditions.
  • It is available as eye drops in markets.

Nabumetone
  • It is a pro-drug used for osteoarthritis.

Piroxicam
  • It is the longest-acting NSAIDS
  • It undergoes a process called Enterohepatic recycling, which is why it is considered as longest acting NSAID

Phenylbutazone
  • Bone Marrow suppression

questions.text: Which of the subsequent options is an abortifacient, derived from synthetic PFG2 alpha?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option d. Carboprost.

Prostaglandin Analogue

Uses

Dinoprost (PGF2 alpha)

- Induction of labor

- Treatment of postpartum hemorrhage

 

- Control of uterine bleeding

Dinoprostone (PGE2)

- Cervical ripening

- Induction of labor

 

- Termination of pregnancy (medical abortion)

Misoprostol (PGE1)

- Termination of pregnancy (medical abortion)

- Cervical ripening

- Prevention and treatment of postpartum hemorrhage

 

- Prevention of gastric ulcers in certain cases

Carboprost (PGF2 alpha)

- Termination of pregnancy

 

- Prevention and treatment of postpartum hemorrhage

questions.text: Which of the following helps in maintaining the patency of ductus arteriosus ?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - PGE

Prostaglandin Analogue

Uses

Prostaglandin E1 (PGE1)

Used to maintain the patency of the ductus arteriosus in specific clinical situations, such as newborns with critical congenital heart defects.

Prostaglandin F2α (PGF2α)

 Has various therapeutic applications, such as induction of labor or treatment of glaucoma.

Prostacyclin (PGI2)

 Has therapeutic applications such as treatment of pulmonary hypertension. Also has anti platelet effect.

options.label: D
options.text: Binds to tubulin and inhibits granulocyte migration

questions.correct_answer: D. Binds to tubulin and inhibits granulocyte migration

questions.text: Which of the following is the compound that prostaglandin, indicated for multiple conditions, is derived from?
What is pegloticase used for ?
questions.explanation:
Drug

Pegloticase

Indication

Chronic gout

Mechanism of Action

Breaks down uric acid crystals and lowers uric acid levels

Administration

Intravenous infusion

Dosage

Every two weeks

Use

Treatment of severe gout in adult patients who have not responded well to other treatments or cannot tolerate other treatment options

Not for use in

Rheumatoid arthritis, psoriatic arthritis, or other forms of arthritis

questions.text: NAPQI is the metabolite of which of the following drug toxicity?
Methotrexate usage causes reduced synthesis of:

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with complaints of urine hesitancy and retention of urine comes to ER. On investigation, his USG shows residual urine of 130 ml. Which of the following drug is used in the treatment of this patient?

questions.text: A physician prescribed a drug that reduces the synthesis of uric acid for the gout. Identify the drug.
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer D - Allopu

Drug

Mechanism of action

Side effects

Allopurinol

Xanthine oxidase inhibitor

Rash, diarrhea, nausea, liver function test abnormalities

Febuxostat

Xanthine oxidase inhibitor

Nausea, rash, liver function test abnormalities

Probenecid

Uriosuric agent

Rash, gastrointestinal symptoms

Colchicine

Anti-inflammatory

Diarrhea, nausea, abdominal pain, myopathy, bone marrow suppression, peripheral neuropathy

questions.text: Which among the following is not preferred as an analgesic in rheumatoid arthritis ?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - K

Drug Class

Examples

Mechanism of Action

Nonsteroidal Anti-inflammatory Drugs (NSAIDs)

Ibuprofen, Naproxen, Celecoxib

Reduce inflammation and relieve pain

Disease-modifying Antirheumatic Drugs (DMARDs)

Methotrexate, Sulfasalazine, Hydroxychloroquine

Slow or stop>

Biologic DMARDs

Adalimumab, Etanercept, Infliximab

Target specific immune system components involved in inflammation

Janus Kinase Inhibitors (JAK inhibitors)

Tofacitinib, Baricitinib

Inhibit Janus kinase, an enzyme involved in immune system signaling

Corticosteroids

Prednisone, Methylprednisolone

Reduce inflammation and suppress the immune system

questions.text: A patient on aspirin presented with occult blood in the stool. This occurs due to the inhibition of ________ by aspirin.
questions.explanation:
Aspirin

MOA

Inhibits cyclooxygenase (COX) enzymes, particularly COX-1 and COX-2. COX-1 is involved in the production of prostaglandins and thromboxane.

Effect on platelets

  • Thromboxane A2 is a potent pro-inflammatory and pro-thrombotic molecule that promotes platelet aggregation and vasoconstriction.
  • By inhibiting COX-1, aspirin reduces the production of thromboxane A2, which leads to decreased platelet aggregation and a reduced tendency for blood clot formation, which can contribute to gastrointestinal bleeding, including the presence of occult blood in the stool.

Uses

  • Analgesic: Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Antipyretic
  • Antiplatelet: Post Myocardial infraction and CVA

Adverse effects

0.5-2 g/day - analgesic dose

  • Nausea and vomiting
  • Epigastric discomfort

3-5 g/day - anti-inflammatory dose

  • Salicylism - vertigo, hyperventilation, tinnitus, reversible loss of hearing
  • Hepatitis
  • Hypersensitivity

Reye’s syndrome: A rare condition seen when salicylates are given in children suffering from viral infections such as influenza, presenting as acute liver failure.

questions.text: Urine alkalinization will be most useful in toxicity of which of the following drugs?
questions.explanation:
Aspirin Toxicity:

Explanation
  • Aspirin stimulates the brain's respiratory center, causing hyperventilation (↓CO2 levels) and respiratory alkalosis
  • The kidneys excrete more bicarbonate to counteract respiratory alkalosis, resulting in metabolic acidosis (Compensatory metabolic acidosis). High doses of aspirin can disrupt oxidative phosphorylation and kidney function, exacerbating metabolic acidosis

Dosage and Toxicity
  • Therapeutic Dose: 3-5 g/day can cause mild chronic toxicity (salicylism)
  • Toxic Dose: Acute ingestion of 10-30 g in adults can be lethal, with much lower doses (4 mL of methyl salicylate) posing a significant risk in children

Clinical presentation
  • Salicylism: Headache, dizziness, tinnitus, reversible hearing and vision impairment, drowsiness, vomiting, hyperventilation, electrolyte imbalance
  • Severe toxicity: Dehydration, high tone deafness, confusion, petechial haemorrhages, hyperpyrexia, seizures, hypoglycemia, psychosis, coma

Management

Treatment is supportive and includes gastric lavage, correction of metabolic acidosis, vitamin K supplements and urinary alkalinization with intravenous sodium bicarbonate to enhance salicylate excretion. In severe cases, hemodialysis may be necessary.

questions.text: What medication is administered to prevent chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting in a 45-year-old woman with lung adenocarcinoma who has experienced these symptoms during her previous treatment visits?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer D - Palonosetron

5HT-3 Antagonists (Anti-motility drugs)

5HT-4 Agonists (Prokinetic drugs)
  • Block 5HT-3 receptors in the gastrointestinal tract and central nervous system.
  • Decrease intestinal motility and secretion.
  • Inhibit the chemoreceptor trigger zone (CTZ) in the area postrema, reducing nausea and vomiting.
  • Activate 5HT-4 receptors in the gastrointestinal tract.
  • Increase gastrointestinal motility and secretion.
  • Enhances the release of acetylcholine from enteric neurons.
  • Ondansetron
  • Granisetron
  • Dolasetron
  • Palonosetron
  • Alosetron
  • Metoclopramide
  • Cisapride (withdrawn due to QT prolongation)
  • Tegaserod (restricted use due to cardiovascular risks)
  • Chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV)
  • Postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV)
  • Radiation-induced nausea and vomiting (RINV)
  • Irritable bowel syndrome with diarrhoea (IBS-D): Alosetron
  • Gastroparesis
  • Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)
  • Functional dyspepsia
  • Chronic constipation
  • Postoperative ileus
  • Headache
  • Constipation
  • Dizziness
  • Fatigue
  • Prolonged QT interval (rare)
  • Diarrhea
  • Abdominal pain
  • Nausea
  • Headache
  • Prolonged QT interval (Cisapride, Tegaserod)

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with diffuse abdominal pain. He has a known history of chronic NSAID usage. Physical examination reveals rigidity. An X-ray of the abdomen is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer C - Peptic ulcer perforation

Adverse effects of NSAIDs

System

Side effects

Additional information

Gastrointestinal

Nausea and vomiting

Selective COX-2 inhibitors: Less likely to cause GI side effects

GI hemorrhage, erosion, Ulcers

Due to ↓prostaglandin synthesis, leading to loss of mucosal protection

Hematological

Platelet dysfunction → Increased bruising and hemorrhage risk

From reduced thromboxane A2 activity

Renal
  • Renal dysfunction/failure
  • Reduction in efficacy of loop diuretics & antihypertensives
  • Salt and water retention
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Acute tubular necrosis
  • Renal papillary necrosis
  • Interstitial nephritis
  • Analgesic nephropathy

Analgesic nephropathy leads to renal failure with papillary necrosis and chronic interstitial nephritis, which is less common since the ban of phenacetin.

 

Cardiovascular
  • Precipitate heart failure
  • Edema

Hepatic
  • Elevated liver enzymes
  • Hepatic failure

Hypersensitivity

 
  • Urticaria
  • Flushing
  • Anaphylaxis

Dermatological
  • Steven-Johnson syndrome
  • Photosensitivity

questions.text: A patient presents with acute swelling in the big toe, and his serum uric acid levels were increased. The doctor prescribed medicine to manage this acute condition. What is the mechanism of this drug?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer D - Neutrophil chemotaxis prevention

Drugs for acute attack of gout

DOC- NSAIDS (All types)

  • Except for aspirin and paracetamol
  • Anti-inflammatory

Colchicine  (spindle poison)
  • MOA: Microtubule inhibitor
  • Used in acute attacks of gout and familial Mediterranean fever and is also the DOC for karyotyping

Corticosteroids
  • Intra articular injections, avoid oral route
  • Immunosuppressive and anti-inflammatory

Drugs for chronic gout

Xanthine oxidase inhibitors  (Option C)
  • Drugs include Allopurinol (DOC), Oxipurinol, Febuxostat
  • MOA: Blocks xanthine oxidase enzyme → Inhibits the conversion of hypoxanthine to uric acid in the liver.

Uric acid oxidase enzyme
  • Drugs include Pegloticase and Rasburicase
  • MOA: Uric acid is converted to allantoin and excreted in urine

Uricosuric agents (Option B)
  • Drugs include Probenecid, Benzbromaron, Sulfinpyrazone, Lesinurad
  • MOA: Inhibit OATP transporter/URAT-1 in the kidney → inhibits reabsorption of uric acid → increased excretion of uric acid.

 

(OATP - Organic anion transport protein, URAT-1 - Uric acid transporter)

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used in the closure of patent ductus arteriosus?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer C - Indomethacin

Uses of NSAIDs

NSAIDs are avoided in
  • Analgesic (in all types of pain except neuropathic pain)
  • Antipyretic
  • Anti-inflammatory
  • Antiplatelet
  • Tocolytic
  • Closure of PDA
  • Pregnancy (as it causes premature closure of ductus arteriosus)
  • Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD)
  • Safest NSAID in these cases is paracetamol.

questions.text: A student complains of developing urticaria following the consumption of seafood. Considering the need for non-sedating medication due to an upcoming exam, which of the following drugs would you choose to prescribe?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer D - Fexofenadine

Generation

Drug

Side Effects

Generalised Uses

1st Generation

 

Diphenhydramine (Option B)

Sedation, drowsiness, dry mouth, blurred vision

Allergy symptoms, Insomnia, Motion sickness

Chlorpheniramine (Option A)

Sedation, drowsiness, dry mouth

 

Allergy symptoms

Hydroxyzine  (Option C)

Anxiety, Allergy symptoms, Pruritus

2nd Generation

Loratadine

 

Minimal sedation, dry mouth

 

Allergy symptoms, Urticaria

Cetirizine

Allergy symptoms, Itchiness, Urticaria

Fexofenadine

Non-sedating, minimal side effects

Allergy symptoms, Chronic idiopathic urticaria

Drug Class

Examples

Mechanism of Action

Xanthine Oxidase Inhibitors

Allopurinol, Febuxostat

Inhibit xanthine oxidase, the enzyme involved in uric acid production

Uricosuric Agents

Probenecid, Lesinurad

Colchicine

Colchicine

Inhibit inflammation and reduce gout attacks

Nonsteroidal Anti-inflammatory Drugs (NSAIDs)

Ibuprofen, Naproxen

Reduce inflammation and relieve pain

Glucocorticoids

Prednisone, Methylprednisolone

Reduce inflammation and relieve pain

questions.text: A 56-year-old male comes to the outpatient department for a routine health check-up. The patient is obese and has smoked for 30 years . His past medical history includes hypertension for 10 years and diabetes mellitus for 8 years , for which he takes amlodipine and metformin pills regularly. On examination, his blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg , and lab findings reveal a cholesterol level of 170 mg/dL. The physician prescribes aspirin to prevent ischemic heart disease . This drug prevents ischemic heart disease by which of the following mechanism of action?
questions.correct_answer: A. Inhibiting TXA2 synthesis by platelets
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Inhibiting TXA2 synthesis
